Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
SciGirls is a multimedia project designed to encourage and empower more girls to pursue careers in STEM. It is a bold and unique experiment--the first television series on PBS designed specifically for girls aged 8-13. The approach is based on the findings of prior gender research. The television show and the Web site are integrally linked. Episodes are available for distribution on many of the newest digital platforms, e.g., Vimeo and iTunes for downloads, free of charge. SciGirls launched in February 2010 and reaches over 80% of the country. This project will support further research and development to advance SciGirls' online and outreach activities. Specifically, the deliverables include: (1) enhancement of the SciGirls website on pbs.org; (2) maintenance of the SciGirls Educator Networks and outreach to new partners; and (3) R&D on other media platforms.

The project's two strategic partners are the National Girls Collaborative Project (NGCP) in Seattle and The Franklin Institute in Philadelphia. The NGCP links SciGirls with its network of 500 community-based science programs for girls, and The Franklin Institute coordinates an affiliate network of science museums to implement SciGirls' outreach activities. The project will also work with the Girl Scouts of America's new "Girl Scout Leadership Experience" program, which emphasizes STEM learning. The most significant web component is a social networking feature that allows girls who are interested in science to connect with peers across the nation. To date, there have been over 300,000 unique visitors and 20,000 registered "SciGirls."

POR.DRECONTENT:
SciGirls is a new PBS television series and website designed to leverage the power of media to encourage more girls to pursue engineering and science careers. Each SciGirls episode follows a different group of girls and their mentors as they explore science and engineering in their everyday lives. The NSF grant #1011045 “SciGirls Season 2” significantly extended the impact of the first season of SciGirls on PBS (NSF #0813519, “SciGirls - A New National TV Series”) through its website, national educational outreach programming and professional development for informal and formal educators. The entire approach to SciGirls is rooted in a set of research-based strategies, the SciGirls Seven, proven to engage girls in STEM. Furthermore, SciGirls takes a unique, holistic approach to STEM subjects, purposefully integrating math with technology with science with engineering.

This grant supported three primary initiatives that increased the impact of the SciGirls series on children, parents and educators.

THE SCIGIRLS MUSEUM AFFILIATE NETWORK: This consortium provides informal educators at science centers nationwide with best practices for employing the SciGirls Seven strategies and educational activities within their institutions. The network grew to 20 member museums, supported by a customized online training system and social-networking platform. More information can be found at www.scigirlsconnect.org.

SCIGIRLS WEBSITE: The website, located at pbskidsgo.org or scigirls.org, launched with the premiere of SciGirls Season One in 2010. Since then the site has received almost 2 million visits from over 500,000 unique visitors, with over 5 million page views. More than 50,000 girls have registered to become SciGirls, and more than 400 science and engineering projects have been uploaded.  “Season 2” funding supported the addition of the site’s first game, Diorama-O-Rama, an environmental science challenge. The unique merging of the TV series and the website  earned SciGirls a National Daytime Emmy Award in the "New Approaches" category.

REPEAT BROADCASTS: The grant supported repeat broadcasts of the SciGirls series. The episodes have been broadcast over 15,000 times on 350 PBS stations, reaching 86 percent of U.S. TV markets. Estimated gross audience has reached nearly 10 million viewings.  The programs are also available online at scigirls.org and as podcasts on iTunes.

The work of this award laid the foundation for a subsequent NSF award  # 1114739, “SciGirls TV Series, Website and Outreach - Season Two,” for the creation of ten new episodes of the series plus new, integrated website features and educational initiatives. The new SciGirls episodes will premiere in the fall of 2012.
